text: The Science Fiction Radio Show, a commentary on science fiction today, presented by the Permian Basin Science Fiction Association. This is David Cruz, Daryl Lane, and David Carson. The subject of this show is social science fiction and satire. Almost any science fiction book concerning the future will suggest a future society. A novel on space exploration will imply technology and social motivation behind the exploration. Robot stories usually describe society's reaction to humanoid machines. But there are a rather large class of novels and stories that deal primarily with societies of the future. Narratives in which the focus is on the structure of future societies, the societal attitudes, religion, mores, personal lifestyles, and the politics of an extrapolated future. Sometimes these books are critical in their speculations about where mankind and his social institutions are heading. Sometimes they are outright depressing and pessimistic. At other times they treat the subject with humor or satire, either of a gentle or biting nature. It is in this area especially that one can perceive the unique values of science fiction, since novels of the future allow for serious speculation on both the immediate and far-reaching destiny of man. Some of the greatest science fiction novels of all time belong to that category of social science fiction. And that type of imaginative fiction, with a strong social comment, has an awfully long tradition behind it. I think you can take it back at least to Plato's Republic, back in classical days. Then Sir Thomas More, in the Renaissance, of course, had his famous utopia, which dealt with the future society. Francis Bacon wrote The New Atlantis in the early 17th century. And at the end of the 19th, Samuel Butler published Erwan, and Ralph Bellamy published Looking Backward, both in regard to future societies. But the master, H.G. Wells, many of his books dealt with societies of the future. The Time Machine of 1895 described a future society very pessimistically. When the Sleeper Wakes, almost at the turn of the century, did the same thing. Wells also, in his War of the Worlds, described what it might be like if England, or Great Britain, the great colonizer of their time, was invaded by a technology vastly superior to theirs, as England was invading Africa at that time. That could be considered sort of a satire. I think probably his deepest treatment of a future society, there would be Men Like Gods, published in 1922. That's a little later than most of his other books. And in it, he dealt with overpopulation, the misuse of science. He described a world teetering almost chaotically on ruin. And his solution to it was birth control and the elimination of the unfit, in order to get society, to get it moving again. But probably the two classics, two classic novels of this century, which describe future societies and set the tone for almost all of the other treatments of them, would be Huxley's Brave New World in 1932 and Orwell's 1984, published about halfway through the century. These two novels show us two different styles or approaches to the social commentary. In Huxley's Brave New World, we see a dystopia caused by technology, the genetic engineering that is involved, as opposed to Orwell, where here we have a system that is politically repressed. It is not necessarily the technology that's caused this. It's a political thing. Yes, in Huxley's Brave New World, he used a sort of class society which divided people up into various levels. The alphas were the elite of the system. They were the makers of the government. And then it went on down to betas and gammas and epsilons and deltas. And each one had various functions that they carried out. The alphas and betas and gammas and so on were brought about through genetic engineering. They were individually engineered so that they would have special abilities, some having higher levels of thought and some having greater levels of manual dexterity. The others set up for heavy labor and lifting and stuff like that. Of course, that class system, that regimentation you mentioned, comes about because of the science, the technology, which the people have no choice. In other words, they're engineered to be what particular class they're in. But in Orwell, that kind of regimentation is due to politics rather than science or technology. Orwell was caught between two authoritarian dictators, I guess you'd say. Hitler was right behind him when he was writing his book and Stalin was right in front of him. So it was almost natural that he would deal with politics in his dystopian society. Several of the catchwords from the book have remained faithful throughout the years, although the original reasons behind them, that being them slanted towards Stalin and his secret police, people still use the term big brother when they talk about, oh, the IRS, some of the government agencies like the CIA. Any political entity that seems to repress the people is referred to as big brother. It's become a phrase unto itself, even away from the book. Of course, many of the things that Orwell showed the government using, communication, spy devices, and so forth, we still have them today. He was extrapolating from the knowledge and the science of his day, and of course those extrapolations have come true. Another thing he used in the novel was a term called new speak, which was really a new language where specific terms and references to what the government didn't like, such as anti-government activities, were deleted from the language. There were no words to define those particular types of anti-government idioms. One of the party's prime sayings was, who controls the past controls the present, and who controls the present controls the future. And the society was strictly controlled. Everybody was watched all the time, and that means all the time when you're at home, in your house, where you're outside. You're always being monitored by some sort of sophisticated telecommunications devices. I believe we'd have to say, too, that that's one of the more pessimistic, futuristic, futurian or dystopian novels, and that the ending doesn't really, is not really upbeat or not very hopeful. The protagonist in the novel thinks he's broken away at least somewhat from the society, but he is found out and brought into the Ministry of Love, which is really the police, and they interrogate him and eventually put him through some severe behavioral modification techniques, and he is brought about to once more being an integral part of society, thinking Big Brother is good for him, thinking the party is watching out for him, and once more becomes a complacent cog in the wheel. The point is perhaps an examination of whether or not society can be controlled to the point where people will forget that they're human and will forget their drives of going on and progressing, and whether they can be satiated with all of their needs met by the society itself. I think we might also divide our discussion into two areas here. Now, all of these novels, of course, deal with the future. But some of them are more aimed at simply commenting on future societies, whether they think they're going to be good ones or not, whereas others are actively satiric, in which they make fun or criticize certain aspects of today's society. But I think one of the better-known novels, which is, I think, mostly one of social comment, pessimistic though it is, is Bradbury's Fahrenheit 451, which, when you look at the date of publication, 1953, is surprisingly enough only four years later than Orwell's 1984. But I think it does stem from Huxley. Fahrenheit 451 does. In that, it's the technology which is dominant. Our electronic media-oriented society has done away with books, and the people are subject to electronics. They are a rather complacent populace. They sit around and watch television all the time, and the television is huge. It covers the entire wall. In fact, it can cover three walls in a person's house. If they provide for the society or for the state to their best ability, they may actually get a fourth screen and have a room that completely surrounds them with television. Bradbury does have, I think, some ingenious things in the novel. For instance, the fireman, one of the, well, the main character is a fireman. Their job is to start fires rather than put them out. And the fires they start, of course, are book-burning fires. Anybody who's caught with a book is guilty of a social sin. And it's near the end of the book that the protagonist, who's escaped his fireman's job and is trying to get away from the hound, the electrical hound, which is chasing him, and he runs across from misfits, some bums or some hobos down by the river. And each one of them is a book. He has totally memorized one of the classics from the past and knows it word by word, line by line, so that even though they no longer own books or have access to them, they still remember the great ideas from the past simply because they've memorized them and try to keep themselves intact and safe so that they can retain this knowledge. In essence, his novel starts out as a dystopia, but ends up having a sort of glimmer of hope at the end of it, at least that these ideas from the past, these great works will not perish, but will be kept alive, handed down to the agents by word of mouth. This last aspect of the book was treated very well, I think, in the 1966 film of this book made by Francois Truffaut. The scene of the book learners at the end is one of the more marvelous things in that film. The mood is just right with each person spouting off part of the book that he knows, memorizing it and remembering it, and the old man teaching his knowledge to the young man so that that will be passed on from generation to generation. You know, it's remarkable how many movies of a science fiction nature have this type of social comment as their purpose. It's almost as if Hollywood has taken its special province, the kind of science fiction novel or story which would describe a future society, and there have been many of them, you know, going all the way back into the early days of moviemaking, as far back as, oh, the 20s, the 30s, things to come. In that particular film, in the story it was adapted from, which was called Shape of Things to Come, Wells speculates on what the future might be after an upcoming war, which he visualizes in that. The future is fairly bleak, at least in Great Britain, until the airmen come over from the Mediterranean and help them set up a new civilization, and through technology, they eventually rebuild the Earth. It's fairly optimistic. We also might mention the movie THX 1138 by George Lucas. This was prior to the time when Lucas wrote and produced American Graffiti and then followed it by Star Wars. This particular movie was about a dystopian future where everybody lived underground in an extremely regimented society where sex was forbidden. People were kept in control by use of drugs. Whenever they began to feel good or feel bad, they simply went to the medicine cabinet in the bathroom, opened it up, and told the medicine cabinet how they felt, and it would dispense drugs to take care of how they felt. It would make them feel back in a complacent, compliant mood that was condoned by the government. Soylent Green came out in 1973. That was from a novel by Harry Harrison entitled Make Room, Make Room. And it's one of the classic overpopulation novels. In this case, it's food that they're running out of. And the population is fed by sort of biscuits or crackers of different colors. And the protagonist, played by Charlton Heston in the movie, investigates and by the end of the movie finds out a horrible fact that the crackers or the biscuits that people are now eating, called Soylent Green, are made from disposed of bodies, human bodies. And the movie ends on that rather grisly note. We better mention just a few other significant novels of social comment before we get on to satire. John Brunner, a 1976 public Shockwave writer, and I think that should be mentioned. Brunner's been called a master of sociological extrapolation. He's a writer on society. That's his thing. And in that book, he pictures a 21st century America which is totally based on computers and data processing. This is a technology that has shaped society. And you have a plug-in society which has developed. The computer is everywhere. People plug into it, get their directions, tell the government what they're doing and so forth. And the hero named Nick learns how to alter the computer's databanks, which reveals a government manipulation of people and so forth. At the end of the book, you get the impression that maybe something is going to be done about it. This kind of repressive computer society might be overthrown. A similar concept was brought forth in Ira Levin's This Perfect Day, written in 1970. And as usual, as you might expect, Larry Niven and Jerry Pornell get into the act. They cover almost every category of science fiction you could think of. Their 1976 novel, Inferno, I think would have to be considered an important novel of social comment. What they did was rewrite Dante's Inferno in science fiction terms and explore different facets of human psychology. I'd like to mention also one other novel that would fit in this category. A very optimistic novel called Inferio by Jack Vance. It's set on another planet, but it is a human society. This is far in the future when humans have expanded into space onto many planets. We have a society here that is repressed by a system of lords and ladies who live away from the common people. And the people are known for their handcrafted work. And they are kept doing this handcrafted work. They're repressed in the way that they cannot produce anything that's duplicated, not even printing. One of our people on the planet, the protagonist, breaks away from the society because he feels like their life is really meaningless. It's just the same old thing every day, in and out. He breaks away from the society and then eventually shows them the error of it and changes the society for better. Another way that an author might comment on society or some of the problems that he sees in society is by using satire, where he can poke fun with humor at what's happening in society, or he can bitterly criticize what's going on in society. I think the classic here would be The Space Merchants. It was originally published as a novelette called The Gravy Planet, and I think it was 1952 edition of Galaxy. Cyril Kornbluth and Frederick Pohl, of course, collaborated on it. But probably in terms of pure satire and also pure extrapolation from the present, this novel, I think, would be above most others. It's a totally advertising society. Consider how much time, effort, influence that advertising has in our society today. Some people think, you know, The Hidden Persuader, for instance, by Vance Packard, was a study that illustrated the importance of advertising. And what Kornbluth and Pohl have done is to set up a society where the total society, from the government on down, is based on advertising. The heroes of the society are so-called copysmiths, people who are master advertisers, masters at molding the minds of the people. One of the phrases in advertising, cutthroat competition, is brought into a grim reality here in that if one of your competitors in advertising comes up with an idea that you want, you can literally declare war on him and physically go out and attack his corporation and win from him that specific contract. The world in which this particular novel takes place is overpopulated and the resources have been drained. And the protagonist is the head of a project which will take a lot of the populace off to Venus to mine for specific minerals and metals to refurbish the resources on Earth. And what they have to do is convince the populace that it's a good thing to go to Venus because it's a wonderful place. Whereas in actuality, they know that Venus is a horrible place and they're going to have to live in domed underground cities and whatnot. But that turns out to be the solution to the novel because the basic conflict is between the leaders of this advertising society and a group of conservationists called the Consies. And the Consies feel that man has to get off the Earth. His whole value system has to change and he has to get off the Earth to do that. So they sort of help and use the protagonist at the same time, the one involved with the Venus Project, they help him so that this campaign is successful and their people, the conservationists, are the ones who go to Venus. And I think we're supposed to believe they will start a new vital society on that planet. One of the things that helps the protagonist make up his mind about the Venus Project and what he's going to do with it is he's kidnapped in Antarctica and his death is faked and he's sent off to some synthetic yeast farms in Costa Rica as a lowly consumer. And he gets to see life as a consumer, whereas before he's been a high executive and he's had special privileges that went along with that rank. And once he sees society from the other side, he believes there are certain things that he wants to do about it in order to change society. The style of the novel, I think, should be called a prospective reader's attention, too. It's very cleverly done. There are many puns. There are many restatements of present little sayings or advertising cliches and so forth, which are extrapolated and changed a little bit for this novel. And it causes a great deal of humor. And I think that kind of humor and that kind of biting criticism that the authors put into the book definitely qualified as a work of satire. Not just simple social comment, but they are satirizing our present-day society and the importance we give to business and advertising. Another novel which satirizes advertising is The Big Ball of Wax by Shepard Mead, written in 1954. It does to television what space merchants does to advertising in general. It extrapolates on what television might become, at least from the viewpoint of a person who was living in the 50s. It shows how it dominates his life through advertising and courses him into buying products, which he might generally, if he had time to think about it, he wouldn't buy. And it dehumanizes the news by using dolls to reenact various natural disasters and crimes, whereby people don't actually see human suffering. All they see are these little dolls reenacting the specific tragedies. Both those books, I think, concentrate on specific facets of our present-day society, for instance, advertising or television. But there's another writer, Stanislaw Lim, whose satire is really aimed at almost the whole human race. He'll pick almost everything possible and satirize it sooner or later in some of his works. This satire is of the very, very humorous variety. It's just a joy to read, and there's all sorts of different escapades that he gets his stories into and out of. One novel we might mention in particular is The Siberiad. The concept of the novel is that far in the future, humankind has degenerated, and the robots that they built ages and ages ago have become a civilization unto themselves. There are two main characters. Both, of course, are robots, Trurl and Klappalcius. They are constructors. Their design is to build things. There are all sorts of different kinds of robots, but their main purpose is to build other things, other machines. They get into all sorts of escapades, and usually they're a little bit vying with each other to come up with something a little bit better than the other one did. One episode that might illustrate the idea of satirizing society is a very short one called Trurl's Prescription, and he postulates out in remote space a small planet with small creatures called the Steely Pips, and they live in a very mechanized society, very happy society, until a great comet comes by one day and deposits something, they don't know what it is, onto their planet. But this something, whatever it is, according to the book, flies up, lands on the highest peak, and makes itself comfortable and doesn't budge, but it's an awful nuisance all the same. Well, the Steely Pips call in Trurl, one of the constructors, to see if he can get rid of it for them, because they've tried everything, and they want to know if they can bring him some TNT or dynamite or radiation or whatever he needs. And Trurl says, no, you just need paper, ink, stamps, and seals, sealing wax and thumbtacks and blotters and a teller window and zinc teaspoon, coffee and a mailman. And he proceeds to set up an office and starts sending the creature, whatever it is, summonses and notices, and you will have to vacate by a certain time if you don't sign these particular forms and so forth. Finally, the creature, which has condescended to reply to the notices, is ordered to vacate and has to do so because he's playing along with the system that Trurl set up. At the very end of the story, Trurl explains how this worked to the Steely Pips, who are quite confounded, they don't understand. He says, basically, my dears, the whole thing was quite simple. The moment it accepted the first dispatch and signed for it, it was done for. I employed a special machine, the machine with a big B. For as the cosmos is this cosmos, no one's licked it yet. The B, of course, stands for bureaucracy. Yeah, the stories in the Siberiad, as you say, they belong to almost like a novel with these two characters doing their thing. But they're almost set up like separate little fables. And in some of them, his satire is aimed at much larger things in society. He gets his two characters involved in another adventure near the end of the Siberiad. And they discover a civilization which has reached the highest possible level of development. They call it an HPLD civilization. And they want to learn from these people. Why? What's it like to be in the highest possibly developed state? And these creatures don't want to respond. They're simply stagnant. But finally, they do respond because of certain machinations and certain overtures that the two robots make. And they give the two robots a compound called altruizine. And they say altruizine, if you put it in the water supply of any planet, any city, whatever, will make everyone feel the same way as everybody else does. And this should bring about universal brotherhood. In other words, you can feel exactly what your neighbor, your friend, your relative, whatever is feeling. And this should, you know, cause all violence to stop. Because if you feel something like they do, you'll understand them better. But I think Stanislaw Limb can be somewhat cynical sometimes. And I think this is one instance of it. The two robots do put this substance into the water supply of a planet. And it causes immediate chaos. Everybody feels the pain of everybody else. And they suffer. And they try to do away with the other people so that their suffering will stop. And the whole place just is turned upside down because of humanitarian motives of these two robots. One of the more interesting satirists of our time is Kurt Vonnegut. There's an interesting story behind Vonnegut's work. He's always tried to avoid the label of being a science fiction writer. He realized that science fiction authors are not as highly considered by critics and teachers and scholars and so forth as mainstream writers. So he's always tried to avoid that label. But I would say 75% of his work would have to be classified as science fiction. He's written about time travel, for instance, in Slaughterhouse-Five. He's written about robots and space travel and the Sirens of Titan. Player Piano is considered a classic dystopia of an automated world. Cat's Cradle is a cataclysmic novel with definite science fiction overtones in it. And back in the 50s and early 60s, he published stories in science fiction magazines like Galaxy, Fantasy and Science Fiction, If, Wonder Stories, and so forth. And he's one of the rare writers, I think, who's noticed by critics and readers beyond the circle of science fiction people. And one of his classic satiric stories would be one published in 1961 in Galaxy entitled Harrison Bergeron. In Harrison Bergeron, you see a society where it is mandatory that you be equal to everybody else. If you are an athlete, you're required to wear weights in order to slow you down so you can't move faster than anybody else. If you are exceptionally beautiful, you're required to wear a mask so you won't appear prettier than anybody else. In fact, the government is in charge of enforcing these rules. There's even a United States handicapper general who makes all of the judgments as to whom should wear what kind of a mask and to what degree. And same thing for belts and other devices. There are also devices that fit in the ear that are loudspeakers that will inject very weird sounds or sound effects or crashes or noises to distract an agile mind from being able to think straight. Meaning that they would be smarter or quicker mentally than someone else. That they even enforce that kind of mental mediocrity. And Harrison Bergeron is almost the antithesis of what the society believes in. And he's huge. He's seven feet tall. He's beautiful. You know, has the body of a Greek god. He's also a genius. And he manages to escape all the traps and all the restrictions that the society has imposed on people. And escapes and meets a beautiful ballerina who's been dancing, of course, with lead weights on her body. And they immediately fall in love, this perfect pair, all beautiful, all intelligent, and so forth. And they start to rise dancing in their beautiful dance of love. And also, they're on television at the time that this is going on. And everybody is watching this beautiful happening. And one of the people comes in from the handicappers, the government handicappers, and shoots them with a shotgun and kills them both. And they both fall to the floor dead. And then the scene shifts back to Harrison Bergeron's parents who are watching this program. And his father reenters the room. He's gone out to get a sandwich while all this beautiful stuff was going on. And when he comes back in, his wife has a few tears on her face. And he says, well, what happened? He says, well, something beautiful happened on the television, but I can't really remember what it was. And he says, well, that's the way it ought to be. And then things just keep going on. In conclusion, we might say that it's clear that novels of social comment are among the more thoughtful of science fiction books. Usually, the author is seriously concerned with mankind's future. And is not merely creating a pure adventure story to excite the readers like in Star Wars. It is in this category of satire and social comment that science fiction has contributed most significantly to mainstream fiction. This is David Cruz. Daryl Lane. And David Carson. This has been the Science Fiction Radio Show. A presentation of the Permian Basin Science Fiction Association. In conjunction with KOCV-FM and Odessa College, Odessa, Texas.

in which they make fun or criticize certain aspects of today's society.
But I think one of the better-known novels,
which is, I think, mostly one of social comment,
pessimistic though it is,
is Bradbury's Fahrenheit 451,
which, when you look at the date of publication, 1953,
is surprisingly enough only four years later than Orwell's 1984.
But I think it does stem from Huxley.
Fahrenheit 451 does.
In that, it's the technology which is dominant.
Our electronic media-oriented society has done away with books,
and the people are subject to electronics.
They are a rather complacent populace.
They sit around and watch television all the time,
and the television is huge.
It covers the entire wall.
In fact, it can cover three walls in a person's house.
If they provide for the society or for the state to their best ability,
they may actually get a fourth screen
and have a room that completely surrounds them with television.
Bradbury does have, I think, some ingenious things in the novel.
For instance, the fireman, one of the,
well, the main character is a fireman.
Their job is to start fires rather than put them out.
And the fires they start, of course, are book-burning fires.
Anybody who's caught with a book is guilty of a social sin.
And it's near the end of the book that the protagonist,
who's escaped his fireman's job
and is trying to get away from the hound,
the electrical hound, which is chasing him,
and he runs across from misfits, some bums or some hobos down by the river.
And each one of them is a book.
He has totally memorized one of the classics from the past
and knows it word by word, line by line,
so that even though they no longer own books or have access to them,
they still remember the great ideas from the past
simply because they've memorized them
and try to keep themselves intact and safe
so that they can retain this knowledge.
In essence, his novel starts out as a dystopia,
but ends up having a sort of glimmer of hope at the end of it,
at least that these ideas from the past,
these great works will not perish,
but will be kept alive,
handed down to the agents by word of mouth.
This last aspect of the book was treated very well,
I think, in the 1966 film of this book made by Francois Truffaut.
The scene of the book learners at the end
is one of the more marvelous things in that film.
The mood is just right
with each person spouting off part of the book that he knows,
memorizing it and remembering it,
and the old man teaching his knowledge to the young man
so that that will be passed on from generation to generation.
You know, it's remarkable how many movies of a science fiction nature
have this type of social comment as their purpose.
It's almost as if Hollywood has taken its special province,
the kind of science fiction novel or story
which would describe a future society,
and there have been many of them,
you know, going all the way back into the early days of moviemaking,
as far back as, oh, the 20s, the 30s, things to come.
In that particular film, in the story it was adapted from,
which was called Shape of Things to Come,
Wells speculates on what the future might be
after an upcoming war, which he visualizes in that.
The future is fairly bleak, at least in Great Britain,
until the airmen come over from the Mediterranean
and help them set up a new civilization,
and through technology, they eventually rebuild the Earth.
It's fairly optimistic.
We also might mention the movie THX 1138 by George Lucas.
This was prior to the time when Lucas wrote and produced American Graffiti
and then followed it by Star Wars.
This particular movie was about a dystopian future
where everybody lived underground in an extremely regimented society
where sex was forbidden.
People were kept in control by use of drugs.
Whenever they began to feel good or feel bad,
they simply went to the medicine cabinet in the bathroom,
opened it up, and told the medicine cabinet how they felt,
and it would dispense drugs to take care of how they felt.
It would make them feel back in a complacent, compliant mood
that was condoned by the government.
Soylent Green came out in 1973.
That was from a novel by Harry Harrison entitled Make Room, Make Room.
And it's one of the classic overpopulation novels.
In this case, it's food that they're running out of.
And the population is fed by sort of biscuits or crackers of different colors.
And the protagonist, played by Charlton Heston in the movie,
investigates and by the end of the movie finds out a horrible fact
that the crackers or the biscuits that people are now eating,
called Soylent Green,
are made from disposed of bodies, human bodies.
And the movie ends on that rather grisly note.
We better mention just a few other significant novels of social comment
before we get on to satire.
John Brunner, a 1976 public Shockwave writer,
and I think that should be mentioned.
Brunner's been called a master of sociological extrapolation.
He's a writer on society.
That's his thing.
And in that book, he pictures a 21st century America
which is totally based on computers and data processing.
This is a technology that has shaped society.
And you have a plug-in society which has developed.
The computer is everywhere.
People plug into it, get their directions,
tell the government what they're doing and so forth.
And the hero named Nick learns how to alter the computer's databanks,
which reveals a government manipulation of people and so forth.
At the end of the book, you get the impression
that maybe something is going to be done about it.
This kind of repressive computer society might be overthrown.
A similar concept was brought forth in Ira Levin's This Perfect Day, written in 1970.
And as usual, as you might expect, Larry Niven and Jerry Pornell get into the act.
They cover almost every category of science fiction you could think of.
Their 1976 novel, Inferno, I think would have to be considered an important novel of social comment.
What they did was rewrite Dante's Inferno in science fiction terms
and explore different facets of human psychology.
I'd like to mention also one other novel that would fit in this category.
A very optimistic novel called Inferio by Jack Vance.
It's set on another planet, but it is a human society.
This is far in the future when humans have expanded into space onto many planets.
We have a society here that is repressed by a system of lords and ladies who live away from the common people.
And the people are known for their handcrafted work.
And they are kept doing this handcrafted work.
They're repressed in the way that they cannot produce anything that's duplicated, not even printing.
One of our people on the planet, the protagonist, breaks away from the society because he feels like their life is really meaningless.
It's just the same old thing every day, in and out.
He breaks away from the society and then eventually shows them the error of it and changes the society for better.
Another way that an author might comment on society or some of the problems that he sees in society is by using satire,
where he can poke fun with humor at what's happening in society,
or he can bitterly criticize what's going on in society.
I think the classic here would be The Space Merchants.
It was originally published as a novelette called The Gravy Planet,
and I think it was 1952 edition of Galaxy.
Cyril Kornbluth and Frederick Pohl, of course, collaborated on it.
But probably in terms of pure satire and also pure extrapolation from the present,
this novel, I think, would be above most others.
It's a totally advertising society.
Consider how much time, effort, influence that advertising has in our society today.
Some people think, you know, The Hidden Persuader, for instance, by Vance Packard,
was a study that illustrated the importance of advertising.
And what Kornbluth and Pohl have done is to set up a society where the total society,
from the government on down, is based on advertising.
The heroes of the society are so-called copysmiths,
people who are master advertisers,
masters at molding the minds of the people.
One of the phrases in advertising, cutthroat competition,
is brought into a grim reality here in that if one of your competitors in advertising
comes up with an idea that you want, you can literally declare war on him
and physically go out and attack his corporation and win from him that specific contract.
The world in which this particular novel takes place is overpopulated
and the resources have been drained.
And the protagonist is the head of a project which will take a lot of the populace off to Venus
to mine for specific minerals and metals to refurbish the resources on Earth.
And what they have to do is convince the populace that it's a good thing to go to Venus
because it's a wonderful place.
Whereas in actuality, they know that Venus is a horrible place
and they're going to have to live in domed underground cities and whatnot.
But that turns out to be the solution to the novel
because the basic conflict is between the leaders of this advertising society
and a group of conservationists called the Consies.
And the Consies feel that man has to get off the Earth.
His whole value system has to change and he has to get off the Earth to do that.
So they sort of help and use the protagonist at the same time,
the one involved with the Venus Project,
they help him so that this campaign is successful
and their people, the conservationists, are the ones who go to Venus.
And I think we're supposed to believe they will start a new vital society on that planet.
One of the things that helps the protagonist make up his mind about the Venus Project
and what he's going to do with it is he's kidnapped in Antarctica
and his death is faked and he's sent off to some synthetic yeast farms in Costa Rica
as a lowly consumer.
And he gets to see life as a consumer, whereas before he's been a high executive
and he's had special privileges that went along with that rank.
And once he sees society from the other side,
he believes there are certain things that he wants to do about it in order to change society.
The style of the novel, I think, should be called a prospective reader's attention, too.
It's very cleverly done.
There are many puns.
There are many restatements of present little sayings or advertising cliches and so forth,
which are extrapolated and changed a little bit for this novel.
And it causes a great deal of humor.
And I think that kind of humor and that kind of biting criticism that the authors put into the book
definitely qualified as a work of satire.
Not just simple social comment, but they are satirizing our present-day society
and the importance we give to business and advertising.
Another novel which satirizes advertising is The Big Ball of Wax by Shepard Mead, written in 1954.
It does to television what space merchants does to advertising in general.
It extrapolates on what television might become,
at least from the viewpoint of a person who was living in the 50s.
It shows how it dominates his life through advertising and courses him into buying products,
which he might generally, if he had time to think about it, he wouldn't buy.
And it dehumanizes the news by using dolls to reenact various natural disasters and crimes,
whereby people don't actually see human suffering.
All they see are these little dolls reenacting the specific tragedies.
Both those books, I think, concentrate on specific facets of our present-day society,
for instance, advertising or television.
But there's another writer, Stanislaw Lim,
whose satire is really aimed at almost the whole human race.
He'll pick almost everything possible and satirize it sooner or later in some of his works.
This satire is of the very, very humorous variety.
It's just a joy to read, and there's all sorts of different escapades that he gets his stories into and out of.
One novel we might mention in particular is The Siberiad.
The concept of the novel is that far in the future, humankind has degenerated,
and the robots that they built ages and ages ago have become a civilization unto themselves.
There are two main characters.
Both, of course, are robots, Trurl and Klappalcius.
They are constructors.
Their design is to build things.
There are all sorts of different kinds of robots,
but their main purpose is to build other things, other machines.
They get into all sorts of escapades,
and usually they're a little bit vying with each other
to come up with something a little bit better than the other one did.
One episode that might illustrate the idea of satirizing society
is a very short one called Trurl's Prescription,
and he postulates out in remote space a small planet with small creatures called the Steely Pips,
and they live in a very mechanized society, very happy society,
until a great comet comes by one day and deposits something,
they don't know what it is, onto their planet.
But this something, whatever it is, according to the book,
flies up, lands on the highest peak, and makes itself comfortable and doesn't budge,
but it's an awful nuisance all the same.
Well, the Steely Pips call in Trurl, one of the constructors,
to see if he can get rid of it for them, because they've tried everything,
and they want to know if they can bring him some TNT or dynamite or radiation or whatever he needs.
And Trurl says, no, you just need paper, ink, stamps, and seals,
sealing wax and thumbtacks and blotters and a teller window and zinc teaspoon,
coffee and a mailman.
And he proceeds to set up an office and starts sending the creature, whatever it is,
summonses and notices, and you will have to vacate by a certain time
if you don't sign these particular forms and so forth.
Finally, the creature, which has condescended to reply to the notices,
is ordered to vacate and has to do so because he's playing along with the system that Trurl set up.
At the very end of the story, Trurl explains how this worked to the Steely Pips,
who are quite confounded, they don't understand.
He says, basically, my dears, the whole thing was quite simple.
The moment it accepted the first dispatch and signed for it, it was done for.
I employed a special machine, the machine with a big B.
For as the cosmos is this cosmos, no one's licked it yet.
The B, of course, stands for bureaucracy.
Yeah, the stories in the Siberiad, as you say, they belong to almost like a novel
with these two characters doing their thing.
But they're almost set up like separate little fables.
And in some of them, his satire is aimed at much larger things in society.
He gets his two characters involved in another adventure near the end of the Siberiad.
And they discover a civilization which has reached the highest possible level of development.
They call it an HPLD civilization.
And they want to learn from these people.
Why?
What's it like to be in the highest possibly developed state?
And these creatures don't want to respond.
They're simply stagnant.
But finally, they do respond because of certain machinations and certain overtures that the two robots make.
And they give the two robots a compound called altruizine.
And they say altruizine, if you put it in the water supply of any planet, any city, whatever,
will make everyone feel the same way as everybody else does.
And this should bring about universal brotherhood.
In other words, you can feel exactly what your neighbor, your friend, your relative, whatever is feeling.
And this should, you know, cause all violence to stop.
Because if you feel something like they do, you'll understand them better.
But I think Stanislaw Limb can be somewhat cynical sometimes.
And I think this is one instance of it.
The two robots do put this substance into the water supply of a planet.
And it causes immediate chaos.
Everybody feels the pain of everybody else.
And they suffer.
And they try to do away with the other people so that their suffering will stop.
And the whole place just is turned upside down because of humanitarian motives of these two robots.
One of the more interesting satirists of our time is Kurt Vonnegut.
There's an interesting story behind Vonnegut's work.
He's always tried to avoid the label of being a science fiction writer.
He realized that science fiction authors are not as highly considered by critics
and teachers and scholars and so forth as mainstream writers.
So he's always tried to avoid that label.
But I would say 75% of his work would have to be classified as science fiction.
He's written about time travel, for instance, in Slaughterhouse-Five.
He's written about robots and space travel and the Sirens of Titan.
Player Piano is considered a classic dystopia of an automated world.
Cat's Cradle is a cataclysmic novel with definite science fiction overtones in it.
And back in the 50s and early 60s, he published stories in science fiction magazines like Galaxy, Fantasy and Science Fiction,
If, Wonder Stories, and so forth.
And he's one of the rare writers, I think, who's noticed by critics and readers beyond the circle of science fiction people.
And one of his classic satiric stories would be one published in 1961 in Galaxy entitled Harrison Bergeron.
In Harrison Bergeron, you see a society where it is mandatory that you be equal to everybody else.
If you are an athlete, you're required to wear weights in order to slow you down so you can't move faster than anybody else.
If you are exceptionally beautiful, you're required to wear a mask so you won't appear prettier than anybody else.
In fact, the government is in charge of enforcing these rules.
There's even a United States handicapper general who makes all of the judgments as to whom should wear what kind of a mask and to what degree.
And same thing for belts and other devices.
There are also devices that fit in the ear that are loudspeakers that will inject very weird sounds or sound effects or crashes or noises to distract an agile mind from being able to think straight.
Meaning that they would be smarter or quicker mentally than someone else.
That they even enforce that kind of mental mediocrity.
And Harrison Bergeron is almost the antithesis of what the society believes in.
And he's huge.
He's seven feet tall.
He's beautiful.
You know, has the body of a Greek god.
He's also a genius.
And he manages to escape all the traps and all the restrictions that the society has imposed on people.
And escapes and meets a beautiful ballerina who's been dancing, of course, with lead weights on her body.
And they immediately fall in love, this perfect pair, all beautiful, all intelligent, and so forth.
And they start to rise dancing in their beautiful dance of love.
And also, they're on television at the time that this is going on.
And everybody is watching this beautiful happening.
And one of the people comes in from the handicappers, the government handicappers, and shoots them with a shotgun and kills them both.
And they both fall to the floor dead.
And then the scene shifts back to Harrison Bergeron's parents who are watching this program.
And his father reenters the room.
He's gone out to get a sandwich while all this beautiful stuff was going on.
And when he comes back in, his wife has a few tears on her face.
And he says, well, what happened?
He says, well, something beautiful happened on the television, but I can't really remember what it was.
And he says, well, that's the way it ought to be.
And then things just keep going on.
In conclusion, we might say that it's clear that novels of social comment are among the more thoughtful of science fiction books.
Usually, the author is seriously concerned with mankind's future.
And is not merely creating a pure adventure story to excite the readers like in Star Wars.
It is in this category of satire and social comment that science fiction has contributed most significantly to mainstream fiction.
This is David Cruz.
Daryl Lane.
And David Carson.
This has been the Science Fiction Radio Show.
